In my opinion
It's another shame for me, this anime are finished a long time ago but i start watching this until recently. This anime really show what you would call 'true' friendship. Feel so stupid that i didn't watch this anime sooner. Shit!
The art, for me the chara designs is just normal. Every parts of the charas are normal for me. But that's what made me so impressed by this anime. This anime prove that "don't judge animes by its chara means" ! =P
The sound, this anime also don't have too flashy BGM, mostly there aren't any BGM that fit with the situations. But Irecommend for you all to check the first OP (Paradigm), this OP really suits the anime plot i think (if you check the english translation, you'll know what i mean). You may also check the first ED (Kokoro Na Kara), it's refreshing for those who love mellow-style music.\n
The characters, for the character's personality. I think all of them are personalities which you'll find in most of the animes. A man of virtue with a god level of righteousness, a determined mind pervert, a cheerful with hidden problems heroine, clumsy with a cute reaction, and a cool beauty with cold heart when you irritate her. I think most of you must see them many times.\n
The story, this what made this anime so wonderful. The story is strong enough to make you forget the flawed parts of this anime. You'll find the beautifulness of friendship. You'll see how complicated their problems is enough to make your mind invaded when you sleep (khekhekhe). What's more? The writer have so brilliant idea to amuse us, i think he want to show us how beautiful friendships can be if you do the things right when you clashing with your friends (i think that is the moral message).\n
And the writer didn't used boring way to have it delivered to us. It's make me curious how he managed to think about these strange phenomenons. And all of that phenomenons are just for one goal : to test the bonds of friendship the CRC members have.\n
I don't know why whenever they success to endure the test they given, i want to scream "oh yeahhh" spontaneously. Well sorry for exaggerating, what i try to say is this anime story plot is strong enough to drive your emotion i think.\n\n
I highly recommend this anime for those who love school-life, supernatural\n
This anime's triangle-love parts really have unexpected ending.\n
The school-life parts are also good and fit the 'test their bonds' title.\n
The phenomenons very unique too. Phenomenon where your desires unleashed uncontrollable? This anime rocks!!!

Well , when I first saw the anime , I honestly tought it wouldn't be that good , I tought it would be something like others yet I wanted to try it.
And yeah , it became my favorite anime so far of this summer.. this anime got something catchy and the characters are so different and well-thinked you could say.. For example Iori (

How can I say this..I was actually expecting more of a comedy, from what I picked up from this body-swapping business. I must be a bit biased then, since I don't often watch dramas. 
Simply put, a group of friends hang out in a club room at school. They go through puberty together by swapping bodies and engaging in entangling relationships. A spirit that possessed their teacher gave them a little push to help them with that puberty, and it helped them learn to trust each other and discover themselves in the process. Overall, this anime went through a more serious tone.

Kokoro connect can and most likely will have a profound affect on many people. Kokoro literally means Heart; Mind; Mentality; Emotions; and Feeling. The connection of all those personal things being shared between 5 friends. All of this leading to them to either becoming closer to each other or losing faith in them.
     The story is something of a hit and miss with me. The Story is very slow paced, each arc lasting 4 to 5 episodes. With each ending of an arc having lasting affects on a future one. Swapping bodies, Uncontrollable Impulses, Age regression, and finally Telepathy of innerfeelings. Each of these being a Catalyst for a specific characters story arc. The reason for my Hit and miss comment is that they didn't delve nearly deep enough into Taichi's psyche. I had to go back after i finished to remember why he feel like an Outcast. Overall though the story will make you remember, people will always have more than one side to them regardless how close you may be to them.


At the start of Kokoro I thought the Art was terribly sloppy for the 1st arc. But I was glad i stuck with it because it either grew on me, or perhaps is was that it matched the more comical side of body swapping, or maybe it just got better. I don't know. The characters aren't exactly eye catching either. Though I think it's better this way, just for fact that the characters have such colorful personalities, if they were drawn an any other way it would of taken something from that.


     Kudos to the Japanese cast, there wasn't a single time in the whole show where i would do anything different. Double Kudos to you Heartseed you creeped me the hell out every time you spoke. The BGM isn't anything thing to sneeze at either, during some of the more intense scenes it worked really well.


     Finally to the Character god i wish i could make this an 11. Each character is so well fleshed out that its almost criminal. The only person you don't really get to know is Heartseed but hes played so well it's forgivable. Whether a Character is so scared to the point of hiding herself in there room because she can't control themselves or someone so stressed out with worry they get sick, it's all shown to great affect. It's hard to hate any of the characters for to long just for the fact that Heartseed has such a hold on them you can almost feel the stress you would go through if you had to deal with it. I guess an a way I would of liked Taichi to be a little bit more broken. Just for the fact that everyone else has so much going on, he seems kind of out of place.


     Besides the slight issues with me getting into the show due to the art, this will always stick with me where ever i go. I will most likely be getting this on DVD in the future and read some of the Light novels just because i want to spend a little more time with these characters.


So yes to Watch, Yes to Rewatch, and Yes to supporting it creator.

So, where do I begin?
This show is definitely one of my favorites and so this is the first one I ever wrote a review on. So let's get right into it. This will include the 4 special episodes.
Story - 10
Compared to a lot of slice of life animes that I've watched, especially comic ones, they don't really have a continuos story, but rather have little parts that happen in the character's life every few days or months.
In Kokoro Connect, the story is ongoing for the most part, and is continuos until there's another part (3 parts in total, including the 4 "sequels". The way thatthe events in this series develop the personalities and expose other sides of the characters is fantastic in my opinion and the creators of this anime did really well with it, it touched my, and many others' hearts in the right spot I would say. The fact that everything focuses on the main story, rather than side events is pretty good as well.


In conclusion: Story development was pretty much on point as I see it, it was clear and didn't have too many side stories if at all.


Art - 8

The art was very enjoyable and fitting, but it was definitely nothing special.

The art was not outstanding or unique in any way, and the characters looked a little generic, yet they still had the distinction from other characters in other series and would be recognizable for the most part.


In conclusion: nothing unique, wasn't dissapointing.


Sound - 7

Again, as the art, nothing too special, but the music and sounds were very fitting for the anime, it isn't something that makes the anime itself distinct though.

in conclusion: it's short, just read it.


Character - 9

There are animes in which I love the characters, but not the story as much (that happens if you watch mekakucity actors without actually looking out for the rest of the kagepro parts), but in this series, the characters were just pipes for the situation and not characters that I'd think of in that kind of situation. But the development of how you discover more parts about their personalities and feelings was made very well and can be moving for people relating to the story.


in conclusion: Character development was better than the characters themselves in my opinion, but you might like them after all, they are relatable.


Enjoyment - 10

The anime really moved me when I watched it and made me cry at some point. It touches really sensitive subjects for me, yet do it in such a way I was relieved. As I said, definitely one of my favorite animes.

I'm sure every Slice of Life fan will like this one.


Overall - 10

It overcomes all of it's flaws at the end, because it's an enjoyable and moving series. Have fun watching it :)

~STORY~ 8/10
Kokoro Connect or Hearts Connect in the literal translation is the story about 5 middle schoolers who are part of the Students Cultural society. They basically meet up every evening and try to come up with stuff to publish in their monthly issue. One day , two of the kids (yui and Aoki) discover that they switched bodies . The other members follow suit soon enough . The 5 are confronted by a magical entity(called HeartSeed) who tells them that they are part of his experiment to study human behaviour . And reluctantly they are forced to face various challenges that this being ofunexplained power throws at them, not knowing when it will end..or if it will at all!


~MAIN CHARACTERS~ 


1) Taichi - A very selfless guy , who just cant take it when he sees others suffering and always wants to help. Wrestling fanboy.


2) Himeko Inaba - The strong silent type who really comes forward as the leader of the whole pack .


3) Iyori - A happy go lucky person, who can make just about anyone smile


4) Yui - She's the brawns of this gang . A black belt and skilled fighter with a soft core.


5) Aoki - The Ron Weasley of the group .


~SLICE OF LIFE TAG~ 9.5/10


The anime was really popular. But that success wasnt down to the cutesy stuff or the dark undertones or even the sexually driven scenes. It was more to do with its Slice of Life tag . 


On the surface , the story is mainly driven by the various trials the MCs face. The way they deal with each is unique and entertaining to watch . But the real reason i give so much plaudits to the writers is the excellent story writing. Before you read further, just look above at the description i've given for each of the 5. Their challenges all involve facing off against who they are . Each and every one of these challenges brings the MCs to their knees and face bitter truths about their life. 


Ofcourse these can all be easily missed by most people and be mistaken as just some dark undertones. But look carefully at each of these episodes and you'll see an amazing message hidden in them . The story you may forget over years , but that simple message may probably stay with you for life . Which of the 5 characters you associate with is something you'll have to find out for your own. Once you do , its upto you to discover how that particular message is relevant to you. That is why i personally believe that this anime succeeded so much - because it embraced the slice of life tag better than any other anime I've yet watched (i.e anime that really had any sort of relevance in the real world) . 


That being said , its pretty obvious how well the characters were developed (10/10 for that). 


~SOUND~ 9/10


One can tell an amazing story via anime . But the anime will not become great if it does not have BGM to back it up .. to hit you right in the feels when it matters ( A fact excellently elicited by FMA and FMA Brotherhood -Slightly varied stories yet much different ratings on MAF) . 


Together with a great opening and ending songs, Kokoro Connect has an amazing BGM to make every emotion transmitted to the viewer.


~ARTSTYLE~ 9/10


One word - BEAUTIFUL


~FINAL VERDICT~ 9/10


While the anime invokes the mind to rethink our lives, it does have some flaws. Well i cant really call them flaws, but things that left me disappointed.  For one thing , i can hear the unanimous voice of the fandom for a second season, one which we never got. The manga does have a few volumes after the events of this anime, but it never got a second season. Secondly , a lot of things about HeartSeed were told very vaguely . Going by the trend set by other anime such as Noragami , this could have been a plot device to milk out a second season, or even a reboot with entirely new set of characters. But to this day we have not gotten a second season. 


If you are looking for just a fun time , probably you will be better served elsewhere. But if you do have the patience to actually listen to the message that is being provided via this story , then you wont be disappointed

When I first went into Kokoro Connect, I thought that it's premise was very similar to Yamada-Kun to 7-nin no Majo with a bit more drama and seriousness. It had a bit of melodrama which isn't really my taste but it was still something that was enjoyable to watch.
Story: 9/10
In the beginning, it was the usual switching bodies ordeal, which although is done many times is still entertaining for me to watch.  I really liked their take on all the phenomenons and their realistic effects on people's lives.  The comedy is also pretty funny to me with the few awkward situations that occur.They blended the seriousness and comedic parts of the show together perfectly while still being effective at doing both.  The pacing was to my liking, with something important happening in every episode.


Art: 7/10

The art style of this show isn't really anything special, it looks like the run of the mill anime art style but it was still very clean.  The drawings of the characters look good and fit their personalities very well.  It was put together very nicely but it didn't really stand out to me.  


Sound: 7/10

The soundtracks fit well with the story but not much of it was memorable although the EDs were pretty good.  The song that changes the mood when Heartseed enters was also good.  As for the voice acting, it was very well done especially Inaba's. (Really liked her voice acting for Mordred and Canaan)  Emotions were very well portrayed but I still can't get over characters that are crying.  I think that's just a me thing though because all I wonder about is how the voice actor's face looks like when they are acting out the scene.


Character: 10/10

The five characters were the highlight of this show with every one of them being flushed out with very real pasts and flaws.  I really like their super tightly knit friendship and how they try to understand each other, defining how friendships are suppose to be.  You can see them developing so well together, with everyone helping one another to solve their personal issues as well as becoming more and more dear to each other. Their ways of going about their lives and working together to solve each others problems were well thought out.  The only character I had problems with was Heartseed which I didn't really see having much of a purpose in the story.  I didn't really see any development in Heartseed either, which is why I didn't really like it, but the way they introduced it with the changing mood and atmosphere was notable.  However, all the other characters were excellent.


Enjoyment: 8/10

At first, this anime wasn't really enjoyable because it was a bit melodramatic but if you can get used to that then this anime is pretty entertaining to watch.  Some things were predictable but the character interactions is what kept me intrigued with this show.  


Overall: 8/10

Would recommend to anyone who likes drama, romance and comedy.

Intriguing anime about friendship, love... individuality, AND LOTS OF OTHER HUMAN BULLSHIT. I am not saying that this is bad anime...
**Lets say that the "philosophical problems" are here for more than just as fundamental plot device for good story...**
As anime (story, characters, visuals ...), I love this piece. But, big aspect of it are the (aforementioned) philosophical "somethings". The questions may be thought provoking, but I think that they were pointless (many of these question cant be answered in other way than by speculations, and you just have to choose answer that you somewhat like...), and answers were developed very poorly(kinda "do what makes youhappy") ... which made story less enjoyable, because there were developed through story ... Do not get me wrong, the story was unique and entertaining to watch, but when some of the main protagonist tried to solve for himself one(most) of those questions, it kinda felt like he could as well just ask himself if he wants to be asshole or good person, and after choosing one of those he could just decide on further development by tossing coin...\n\n
**Now let's assume that all the philosophical thing were there just for story and not for you to think about them... **\n
This assumption just sound silly and I can't acknowledge that this maybe the intent of creators....\n\n
To sum it up, many times while watching this, I caught myself really enjoying how easy to watch and beautifully made this anime is. But then (either I remembered or the story delved into it), the philosophical aspect which felt somehow immature and underdeveloped/straightforward ruined that moment for me ... OR maybe I'm just overthinking it...

A fun romance show centered around sci-fi elements. Kokoro Connect starts off strong with an interesting group of friends randomly swapping bodies with each other for a short amount of time. This leads them to learn very personal things about each other, which really strains their relationships but at the same time draws them all closer together.
Ok, I really liked this show and thought the sci-fi elements were cool at first but now I'm going to get into slight spoilers. 
So, the whole body swapping thing is really cool, but that's not the only sci-fi element in the show. Throughout the series, new sci-fi elementskeep getting added. And each new one is substantially less interesting than the last. With that being said, the last 3 or 4 episodes are nearly ruined by the final sci-fi element that gets introduced.\n\n
All the sci-fi stuff had purpose at the beginning of the series, it drew the cast of main characters closer together and forced them to help each other out with their darkest problems. By the end of the series, it just became a nuisance and I found myself wishing I could just enjoy the characters natural development together in a regular way. I really don't want to spoil what these added sci-fi elements are but just be warned, they get progressively more random and annoying.\n\n
That being said, Kokoro Connect is still a really unique show. Romance mixed with crazy sci-fi stuff in a seemingly normal slice-of-life world. I really enjoyed the first 75% of the season, but the ending really left something to be desired. I'd still recommend this to anyone looking for a unique romance show though. Anyway, thanks for reading! 7/10

With anime like these, it makes me wonder exactly where the authors got their ideas, because this one is definitely something special.
Kokoro Connect is about a few high school students with some very peculiar problems, ranging from unstable teenage outbursts and well, lots and lots of drama. But the good kind of drama. You will see revelations happen as the plot and characters unfold to reveal something pretty, unique scenarios. There's a lot to say here, and so much more I could say, but I'll leave that part to you.
The characters are the real juice in this engine. They're all apart of this unique schoolclub called the: Student Cultural Society, or in short, StuCS; which honestly we never quite figure out what the club is really all about. But everything goes downhill as we meet up with HeartSeed, who is the main culprit here. Basically, HeartSeed seems to be some sort of hive-mind type intelligence that feeds off of human emotion in response to what orders he may give them. He takes the persona of Ryuuzen, Gotou and manages to entertain himself with the students of StuCS by tampering with their lives in order to get enjoyment. This may all sound doom and gloom, but I believe his motives aren't for the worse. The students themselves are quite the bunch. Without getting too in-depth, they all seem to be dealing with their own problems, even ones that they might not have known about, and over time see the errors in their ways. They're also all very varied in their emotions, I really felt good connections with them.\n\n
Now for the art, it was well...decent. Nothing too special, but it won't make your eyes ask for more candy. The OP and music is also quite decent, but again nothing special. As where the voice acting is superb, everything else seems to be very mediocre.\n\n
So overall this one is quite the journey, be prepared for a lot of drama and romance, as well as some pretty crazy scenarios. I highly recommend this anime!

I won't hesitate to say that "Kokoro Connect" is, as of this review, my all-time favorite slice-of-life anime. The premise is a well known cliche: the standard body-swapping plot device that filler writers turn to when they run out of ideas. But much in the same way that "Kimi no Na Wa" tells a captivating tale, "Kokoro Connect" uses the body-swap phenomenon to evolve the characters and their relationships. It's not just done to generate laughs (which it does). It helps to tell a story far more profound.
The music and art were fine. Nothing amazing, but still good. The characters, however, never felt to melike one-dimensional archetypes but rather genuinely fleshed out people with their own interests, hopes, and fears. Since each character retains their voice actor no matter who inhabits their body, the characters (and audience) have to determine who is whom from their speech, mannerisms, and personality, a detail I appreciated. The plot is suspenseful and fast-paced, and the comedy at times is laugh-out-loud hilarious. Overall, a solid anime.


And then begins episode six.


Despite exceeding my expectations in almost all areas, I sincerely began to hate this show. It's separated into three arcs, each with their own strange phenomenon occurring to these unlucky teenagers. The first is body-swapping, but I don't even remember the last two because of how convoluted and uninteresting they were. Worse yet, the next eight episodes became like a game show in which the characters constantly tried to one-up each other with their "tragic" backstories and "crushing" traumas.


I finished the show, cringing and eye-rolling most of the way. But then I remembered how much I enjoyed the first five episodes. I believed from the generic plot summary that I was going to regret watching this. I didn't, but I easily could have. "Kokoro Connect" told a better story in five episodes than most anime do in twenty-five. Do yourself a favor and call it quits after the first arc.

I am also including the 4 episode "sequel" in this review. 
I have been meaning to watch Kokoro Connect for a little while now, actually it's been on my to watch list for years. I decided to revisit this short and sweet anime about the daily lives of a few high school misfits, whom I related to more so than I could care to admit, with a few twists along the way. 
High school animes usually diverge into two directions: the cop-out, fan service, sort of vibe, where the characters remain static and one can sit back and enjoy the nothingness and fill the voidof your empty soul with cute girls doing cute things. Or the anime can twist the formula and make it something completely unique and different. Kokoro does the latter. 


But what many anime do is fail to fully flesh out the characters, especially if the show is not more than 24 episodes, as we see here. It's hard to make you, as an outside observer, want to know and care what happens to the characters in such a short amount of time. Kokoro connect takes the traditional anime tropes of character development and actually delves into the lives of the characters, and the secrets they harbor. 


We all know the masks we put on for others is a fake one. You have a mask for your friends, a mask for your family, a mask for your classmates, for your coworkers, the list goes on. We switch our masks and it becomes exhausting, not quite knowing who we really are inside. On the surface interactions are pleasant, but inside we dance with our inner turmoil. So what do we have here? Turns out each character is suddenly thrust into a strange situation, wherein each learns of the other's darkest secrets. 


Of course, it has its flaws. There I think is one too many characters for each character to have a fully fleshed out role, the art is nice but a bit bland, the music is mostly unnoticeable and some of their problems are solved too easily. But overall, it was a solid watch and worth at least a cursory playthrough. 


I'm trying not to give away too many spoilers and leave it general, as I haven't reviewed an anime in years, but Kokoro connect deserves at least an 8 in my book. It is a clever, emotional, slice of life anime that concludes in a satisfactorily way. Perhaps one day my own mask shall fall...

Kokoro Connect is much more than a 'slice of life' with a speck of 'supernatural'. More than that, it is a philosophical exploration of identity and the self, delving deeply into the aspects of what defines a person, a personality, an emotion, and ultimately, the true self. This exploration is undertaken amidst the background of the bonds of friendship and passion, the bittersweet pleasure and pain of love, the maniacal follies of despair and sadness, and the echoing nostalgia and melancholy of the past.
Of particular strength to the the story is the implicit exploration of the concepts of "hon'ne" (本音) and "tatemae" (建前): the unspokenworld of true feelings and desires (hon'ne) and the often contrasting façade of public behavior and opinions (tatemae). The depth to which these concepts of Japanese nature are investigated makes the story a gem for those seeking a philosophical journey inward into the most primordial and fundamental attributes of the self, and the impact of external perception on who we seem to be to others in contrast to who we believe to be ourselves.\n\n
Along the way, a roller-coaster of emotions will swing the viewer through joy and sorrow, assuring that one's heart will forever resonate with the implications presented in the plot. Not a show for those who cannot see past the superficial aspects of a story. Proceed into a journey that will make you inquire the very core of your existence...

In its entirety of 17 episodes, "Kokoro Connect" accomplishes what most anime cannot do in a hundred. Its drama, comedy, and romance meld together in perfect balance - and I do not use that word lightly. Plunged into schemes such as randomized body switching, five students are forced together to sink or swim, and the result is what most shows dream to be. Kokoro Connect is a must-watch!
Story [9/10]: Composed of four main story arcs where the characters are forced into some supernatural occurrence, Kokoro Connect is undoubtedly contrived. Yet that is what allows it to explore its characters and relationships without squandering time tryingto build tension. It also forces the audience to ponder how he/she would handle these phenomena (similar to Death Note). The characters try to be logical and direct within their emotional bounds, creating a compelling story.


Pacing [9/10]: The pacing of Kokoro Connect is incredible! Its writers knew exactly how much could be done in the episode limit, and they filled each minute to its fullest. That is not to say that there aren't scenes which feel a bit slow or rushed, but they are a drop in the bucket. Have you ever wondered what an anime could be if its characters didn't waste half the show waffling and avoiding direct conversation? The result, as we see in Kokoro Connect, is wonderful.


Art [7/10]: Even though there it avoids some drawing-intensive events such as large festivals, Kokoro Connect still keeps its artwork fresh with plenty of movement and changes in scenery. Its style is consistent (no chibi or blobs) and, although nothing remarkable or flashy, is enjoyable to watch.


Sound [6/10]: While the OST may be the weakest link in the series, this is largely because the rest of its elements are so strong. The music is akin to that in most anime.


Character [9/10]: When it comes to characters you enjoy seeing, no amount of screen-time is enough. What we do get, though, are five characters who have their own distinct, non-archetypal personalities. They develop and mature, struggle and succeed. The show is unburdened by side characters/stories, instead deciding to stay focused on these five and their relationships - and in this case, less is more.


Enjoyment [10/10]: Every episode of Kokoro Connect holds its own. It weaves all the threads of character-driven anime - developing relationships, facing past demons, finding self - into a beautiful fabric. I loved it, and would recommend it no matter what your genre preference!


Overall: [9/10]

This series is absolutely phenomenal, even though it may not have the highest rating.  Majority of the overall rating comes from enjoyment in my review, cause even if the story and character is a heaping pile of shit, if the anime makes it work, i'll give them creds.  Okay so here goes..
Story (8) - The story is very interesting, in that you really don't know what's gonna happen next.  The first story arc ended with a BANG and I was almost scared for a minute there.  The biggest problem I can find with the story is that it is forced alot-Balloon Vine comes, does weird phenomenon, big life changer, goes back to normal and cycle continues.  I really didn't know if the anime was supposed to be comedic or dramatic with this, and it became a pain to see the characters just go through the same thing all over again.  It also suffers from a tell-all story, in which the characters have to say what they are feeling instead of it being understood by the viewer through their actions. That being said, the body swapping and and other little moments make the anime totally worth it.


Art (8) - I really liked the art, because it wasn't extremely high quality, and a bit fuzzy, which in a way resembled the relationships between the characters- nothing's solid and nothing's established yet, they're still finding out who they are.


Sound (6) - A lot of ppl like the soundtrack, but i found it pretty mediocre.  It works occasionally but majority of the time the anime is held up by its story and characters.


Character (8) - This anime is really split into underdeveloped characters, overdeveloped characters, and characters somewhere in between.  The UD (underdeveloped) characters would be Aoki and Yui.  The OD (overdeveloped) characters would be Taichi and Nagase.  The in between would be Inaba, which is really the sweet spot of the series.  I'll go down the list.


Aoki is the most bland character in the show.  We only get some form of development for him when he thinks that he doesn't really love Yui, which was his only defining characteristic in the first place.  We get occasional moments of his interactions with Taichi as well, but he has little to no moments with Nagase or Inaba, which probably gives him the least development.  He loves Yui unconditionally, but the anime leaves out one key component to this love, why.  In the entire series, Aoki gives no solid reason for loving Yui except that she's cute and has a nice personality - which personality?  Ultimately, gets a little better but that was from being a horrible character so not much improvement.


Yui is a pretty interesting character in the show.  The show starts off its problem solving with Yui's fear of men-which only pops up at certain times to raise suspense, its extremely inconsistent.  The reason for her fear is good (almost raped), but the anime doesn't even address that seriously, which couldve given it so much more depth.  Aoki loves her, and she loves him too, but why?  This relationship is definitely forced in the show, and there is only one major detriment to it later on.  However, Yui does have a good, developed relationship with Taichi and Nagase, which redeems her unrealistic relationship with Aoki.  However, she has little to no interaction with Inaba (which could've saved her character, explained later).


Taichi is supposed to be the main character of the show, but that spot really should go to Inaba.  He is tagged early on as the selfless member of the group, he loves to solve people's problems.  This made me dislike him out of all the members the most.  I would've been 100% good with taichi if inaba didnt label him as the savior so early on, it wouldve been to nice to see that trait represented through his actions. It wasn't tho and as a result the show goes to far in this trait and overdevelops him by having him solve everyone's freaking problem in this show.  I never really liked his relationship with

Nagase, they are set up by everyone in this show, but they dont click, and for some reason the show thought differently.  However, he gets better as the show goes on, and his unrealistic relationship with Nagase is resolved in the 4 episode extra arc.


Nagase is, sadly the receiver of all the horrible things in this show.  Balloon Vine manages to make her already crappy life even more like hell with each of his pranks.  Her characterization is one of the most sad yet beautiful things in the show, we learn that she still doesn't even know who she is yet cause she has been concealing her real self all these years.  When she changes to who she really is people shun her and tell her to go back to being herself, but she still doesn't even know what that is yet.  Her relationship with Taichi and Inaba complicate this even more.  Inaba forces them together, but we learn later that Nagase doesn't really think they fit.  Even though Taichi is supposed to be the main character in this show, the title really should go to Nagase.


Inaba is the saving grace of this show.  She's easily one of the best developed characters alongside Nagase.  Her main problem is that she suffers from know-all syndrome, which means she KNOWS EVERYTHING ABOUT WHATS GOING TO HAPPEN.  She knows that the phenomenons will either destroy or connect them, which just kills any sort of suspense made.  Apart from this, her intuition is one of the best devices in the show to advance the relationships between the characters.  If you look at the other characters, and how developed they are, that being Taichi and Nagase on the top, they interact a lot with Inaba.  Inaba herself isn't overly developed but serves as a vessel to develop the other characters.  Her attraction to Taichi is an interesting way to develop her character, but the show doesnt do so in a way that makes her seem mindless like Aoki.


Enjoyment (10) -  Absolutely loved it.  All of the components, while not perfect individually, fit together in a way that gave me maximum enjoyment.    Can't reccomend a better show to get the feels out.


Overall (8) - A great series that is essential to become an expert anime watcher. Warning tho: you'll be stuck wondering what happens next so don't binge on school nights :p

This is one of those shows where it's all about the characters and their interactions. The main antagonist exists only to put the main characters in situations that ultimately bring them together. It doesn't really have an over arching story other than the characters and their interactions, so it's kinda like a slice of life in that sense, but it has multiple arcs that tie into each other so not really? It's hard to describe this show other past the basic title of high school romance, but there plenty of feel good moments in this show. But overall I had an amazing time with thisanime so 10/10

Kokoro Connect is an school drama, romantic, comedy that brings great depth to their characters by the supernatural experiences they encounter. My impression of Kokoro Connect soared beyond what I had originally imagined: The following 4 specials have become my favorite set of specials. Kokoro Connect managed to utilize all its supernatural occurrences skillfully, focusing less on overusing them and more on how they affect the five people members of the cultural research club.
The story follows 5 seemly normal youths (Aoki, Inaba, Yui, Taichi, and Inori) who's weaknesses are exposed through the meddling of some higher being. This higher being, Fuusenkazura, essentially just wants toexperiment on the cultural research club for both his and our enjoyment. It is weird that the story never really highlights why Fuusenkazura is toying with the members of the club, but I suppose they are too busy dealing with the mess he causes to be asking questions.


The main character of the story is Taichi, a noble person who honestly wants to help people out, a good character to view the story from as the rest of the cast experience body swapping, uncontrollable impulses, mental telepathy, time reversal, etc.. The story develops all the characters at once, but each event seems to cause the most trouble for specific members of the clubs who in turn of, for example, body swapping become extremely uncomfortable due to their inability to be around the opposite gender.


While I mentioned that Taichi is the main character, it is really hard to make that judgment since most of the characters have equal involvement and impact in the story. Yui is an surprisingly docile girl for somebody who was well known for her martial art skills in middle school. Aoki is always high spirited and excited. He also has a crush on Yui, whom continuous to ignore his feelings, but thankfully Aoki is not annoying. Typically such a character drives me insane, but Aoki fawns over Yui like a 'normal' person would since after all she doesn't just quit the club. Inaba is very mysterious, serious, and looks out for the rest of the club members. Inori is always putting on a smile for everyone and acts friendly to the other members. 


The characters all have their own unique quirks that become apparent as the show continues - I don't want to say anymore since the vast majority of the show is discovering the true identities of the characters and how they change.


The show has no fan service, and none of the supernatural occurrences have any sort of presence in the animation at all. To be honest the art isn't very impactful, but it is still very clean. It does clearly depict the characters emotions, and doesn't detract from the meaning behind their words and actions. 


Overall, I would recommend this show to pretty much anyone. Some of the lessons the characters experience kind of make you reflect on your own life and how you live it. I will say that certain arcs had more impact than others. In finishing one arc I resonated with my heart and made me reflect for a good while. It managed to lift my spirits for a few days to be honest, but that is because it happened to coincide with what I had been thinking about. The show was Great (9), and I had no complaints watching this, so neither should you!

well i thought this anime was really good from the start and so on. They even made the romance really good. which i loved lol but then they started adding all this drama in......... which i just hated... it made me so annoyed that i had to check who he ended up with, well wat i found out dissapointed me alot and after reading some reviews and those fanservice on _____ i just gave up on this anime. like srly =.= half the anime starting out  with this amazing story with these two falling for eacother to back it up, then other half someoneelse comes in just to cause drama and fanservice blaa so annoying such a waste of my time to watch .....

What defines a person? In other words, what is a person's identity? Is it his body? Is it his actions?  Is it his past? Is it his thoughts?
Kokoro Connect explores each of these four answers, one answer per arc, starting with the body-swapping arc exploring the answer of "body". Although Kokoro Connect might not take a proper stance on which answer is "right", it does give more than enough food for thought.
But don't expect Kokoro Connect to be too stressful, since it is fundamentally a romantic comedy slice-of-life show, although not a particularly normal one. It starts out by describing each of the characters'stereotyped personalities, which would normally be a bad idea. However, the show then proceeds to throughly deconstruct every single character, resulting in intriguing character development.


Another thing that makes Kokoro Connect shine is the humor. It has slapstick routines, witty sarcasm, sexual humor, and meta-jokes. But I particularly like how the show likes to make sudden switches from being serious to being comedic, which made me laugh a lot.


To sum it up, Kokoro Connect is a quirky masterpiece. 


P.S. Don't forget to watch the Michi Random arc (episodes 14-17). This series functions more like a 17-episode series than a 13-episode series plus a 4-episode extra.


P.P.S. This is my first review on MAL. Yay!

To put it simply, there are spome scenes/aspects/themes/what-have-you in this series that are super, SUPER cute, just flat out adorable, though that's my opinion. The number of times I squee'd to myself is the sole reason I'm writing this review.
So if you like (what-I-think-are) really cute things, and want to watch a series with an intriguing plot structure, well developed characters, and enjoyable animation, this is more than worth giving a chance.

Letting everyone know this review covers everything in the anime and plus the 4 additional episodes of the Michi Random Arc. The Video Review is out on my channel, but here is the Written Review.
Story - 9/10
The story of Kokoro Connect centers around a group of fives friends, in a High School club, known as the Student Cultural Research Club. What they do in the club in unimportant, it’s what happens to them that is. One day, a supernatural experience happens to them, known as a phenomenon. The phenomenon they experience are swapping bodies, performing their innermost desires, reverting back to a younger age andreading each other’s thoughts. All these supernatural happenings have something in common, it’s all random.


The story focuses on how the characters face the phenomenon, how they handle it. The big overarching theme of the story is, ‘Trust.’ Such as, when switching bodies, can they trust each other not to do anything, that’ll effect their social life, while the original is not in control with their bodies. Or when they can read minds, can really trust each other, after hearing what they said, but the thoughts in the mind is completely different.


Because the phenomenon are random, the plot can get confusing. It’s kind of hard to sometimes tell when a character switches bodies. And the mind reading can happen so fast, it’s possible to miss something. Some of the writing in the plot, can be very over dramatic, which can be annoying. However I think the concept is indeed interesting, trying to go on about your normal routine life, but then suddenly something supernatural happens to you, and you’re completely thrown off. 


Characters - 9/10


Taichi Yaegashi, is the main protagonist of the 5 characters. Well he is somewhat a stereotypical protagonist. When it comes to helping others, he cannot resist lending someone a hand. However it’s because of that trait, it’s considered his fault. It explores on his character, if he really wants to help people, or is it just because he can’t help himself. However he’s also the most reliable because of this trait.


Himeko Inaba is the Vice President of the club. Because she is portrayed as somewhat lonely girl, she is distrustful of the others, however she does worry about them a lot, because she doesn’t want to lose them as friends. Because she has trust issues, she doesn’t really know who she is actually, she begins to question herself, if she does things to make others happy or to make herself happy. I love it how her character doesn’t really fall into any stereotypical character traits. Although she is somewhat a lonely girl inside, she has a sense of seriousness, confidence and even humorous personality side to her.


Iori Nagase is the easy going President of the club, wait easy going? Oh no, after her initial appearance, you think she falls under the stereotypical character trope as being the happy go lucky girl. However because of her past experience with her fathers, she has learned to change personality to fit the situation to make everyone happy. So is she who really who she says she is? Again, they take a basic character archetype and they explore the idea of that character type, because honestly, no one can be easy going all the time.


Yoshifumi Aoki is the other guy member in the club, and also Taichi’s best friend. He has an obvious crush on Yui and always confesses to her. He is actually the only member, the others can truly trust. Because his personality is so expressive, he actually usually does thing care freely. He lives life to the fullest, and brings positive energy to the group. However because he is willing to stay positive throughout the situations, he can be the least interesting of the five.


The last of our five is Yui Kiriyama. Yui has androphobia after she was almost raped in junior high school, so she doesn’t trust the boys. So overtime, her friends help her gain the confidence to hang around the guys. Her personality and trust issues get worse as the story progresses, because even though she learns to trusts the others, its herself she cannot trust. 


What I love about these characters is how they’re developed. When there is drama, the characters react perfectly, although some maybe dramatic more than the others. When character interact with each other, it makes sense on how they interact with each other. And it’s good to see their relationship improve after learning more about each other and helping each other. I also love how the character may seem stereotypical at first, but then the plot and writers take their personalities on a whole different angle.


Animation and Sound - 7/10, 7/10


The art style is rather standard. It works well at looking clean and smooth, but other than it’s not really that interesting or unique. Because most of the time, the characters are just talking with each other, they don’t perform too many action for the animators to drastically do much. However the lighting in the anime looks gorgeous and fits the mood and setting very well. The characters designs are a bit different than other animes, but not too much. Plus it doesn’t get distracted by fan service too much.


The soundtrack fits the mood and setting of the show, however it is really low so it’s very hard to hear. However when you do listen to individually, it’s not too bad. The voice acting is fine, especially Heartseed’s voice, who is the one controlling the phenomenons, he has a very monotone tired voice to suit him. In terms of the Opening and Ending themes, they do their job, only the recognizable themes were the first opening, the michi random, and the first ending themes.


Enjoyment - 9/10


I enjoyed this series because it reminded me of a similar series I previously watched, however with more drama and less humor. I enjoyed the story and concept, I thought the characters were refreshing in a refreshing concept and plot. Although it can be over dramatic at times, it’s when it’s not, it flows so well. I also enjoyed a lot of the humor it had, the humor didn’t distract from the mood too much, and I think the jokes were clever and smart, really fitting for a teen setting. I really loved watching how the relationships unfolded, plus there was an actual love story, that ended in one of the characters actually dating the other, and not going back to the status quo thing. The ending was satisfying for me. It felt like a proper ending, tying loose ends and you can see the characters changes. 


Verdict - 8/10


For the story of Kokoro Connect gets an 9 from me. I love that the story was interesting and unique. I love the different situations the characters were put in and thought they were paced quite well. Plus the ending was satisfying. Little problem was following the story, at times it will be confusing, because the phenomenons jumped quite a bit and can be over dramatic.


The animation and sound both each gets a 7. The art style is nothing special, however it is cleanly and smoothly animated. But nothing special really happens. The lighting is fantastic however, it really suits the mood and settings of the show. The soundtrack suits the atmosphere very well as if you can hear them, it’s a bit hard to hear. The themes are nothing special, they do their job, and they are a good listen.


As for the characters they get a 9 rating from me. Because I found them all interesting and unique. I loved that the writers made me think the characters were stereotypical, but then really change their personalities up to make them unique. I think they were well developed as well. Their interactions and reactions with each other made sense. I think they the whole cast is likeable in one way or another.


For my own personal enjoyment, I give it a 9. Because it really reminded me of Haruhi in a way. But I enjoyed the concept and loved the characters. I think the humor and writing was smart, they made me really love these characters and the genre. I thought the series was paced well, with a satisfying ending.


So after rounding that all up, I give Kokoro Connect an 8/10. It’s an interesting concept with a cast of interesting characters, who are well developed. However the animation and sound is rather standard. I recommend this anime to fans of the slice of life, drama, romance and supernatural genre. I think because of those storylines, the plot can really appeal to those people. However if you’re not into that, it’s fine to skip it, but’s worth your time if you watch it, just don’t expect too many things to happen, because the animation is rather standard. I love the characters, and I believe you love the characters.

First off, this review will also be including the 4 episodes in the Michi Random specials. 
Let me keep this quick and simple. Five students in a club encounter strange phenomenon's caused by something/someone who calls themselves 'Heartseed'. Although it seems light hearted in the beginning of the anime, it's much more complex. As a result of Heartseed's actions, the five students find out a lot about eachother in which they have never shared with anyone before the phenomenon's began. It makes these characters not only learn a lot about their friends, but also about themselves. They discover who they are, and secrets that werehidden beneath exteriors. 


Story - 9/10

The pacing of the anime was good. It wasn't too short or too long and presented the events as they would naturally occur in terms of time. This gave a good amount of time to show character development of each character. It told the stories of different characters and had great character development.  It balanced humour and drama, however why my score isn't a 10 is due to the animes lack of explanation in some parts. If you watch it you'll understand that it leaves you slightly confused, but overall the ending was touching and a nice tie up to all of the events that had occurred. 


Art - 9/10

The design of characters and settings within the anime is simple. Each of the main characters have a cute presentation that add to the simplicity of their character. It articulates that although many have their own personal issues, we hide it behind our exterior whether we look cheerful or stern. 


Sound - 8/10

The voice actors/actresses were perfect for each character. The voice acting was great, and the osts/opening/ending themes were a nice touch to the anime too. 


Character - 8/10

The anime had a nice set of characters who were not perfect at all. One is a selfish freak, another is sensitive due to her past, one feels useless, one doesn't know who she is and one doesn't know what she wants. But these characters show their development as a person through the help of each other and the realisation of how helpful and important their connection and communication to each other truly is. 


Overall - 9/10

Kokoro Connect is about connection. It teaches its audience to value and hold those close to them. It was an enjoyable anime that I do recommend to those who enjoy animes with some meaning or centred around connection/self discovery. It might just be me, but I see this as a very meaningful anime that teaches a valuable lesson to its viewers; to simply live life how you want, and that opening up to other people is sometimes the best way to find who you want to be and solve your problems. Overall, 9/10. Definitely should watch! :)

When i first saw Kokoro connect, I thought that it was your usual teenage drama/high school anime, with slight tinges of romance. When I heard from my friends that the first arc was about body swapping and manipulating the supernatural, i KNEW i had to watch this.
Each character has their own unique traits and behavior and I really liked the way that they interacted with each other. For the Summer 2012 anime charts, I feel that Kokoro Connect is the best out of all the others that have been aired.
I would give a 10/10 for the first arc. The first arc simply outclasses the othertwo arcs that are shown in the anime by a couple of miles. The concept of body swapping is innately a curious topic, everybody wants to know what it is like to step into another's shoes. Kokoro connect takes that and explores the psychological and social consequences of body swapping, rather than merely the comedic side of it like most other animes do.


Heartseed is shown to be a god figure that is able to manipulate the supernatural. And because of his 'godlike' powers, KC's story can expand without restrictions even though the setting and characters are limited. With every power that Heartseed throws them, the characters grow in depth and learn more about themselves, their friends, their parents and solve problems that they would never have been able to solve without Heartseed's meddling influence. 


Story 9/10

Kokoro Connect is a realistic take of a supernatural situation, which is unique for an anime series. The emotional journey between the 5 of them is deep, and the dialogues are simply superb. There is a well thought out balance between drama, comedy and slice of life. Romance, inevitably, is a part of this too, but it's a small part of this anime, like the final dressing on a cake made to perfection.

Although it hasn't quite kicked in during these 13 episodes, Kokoro Connect's storyline is going to be quite repetitive, without a main plot, later seasons of this anime are bound to fail


Art: 8/10

I'm a little biased here, because the art for Kokoro Connect is the same as K-on (my favourite moeblob). The character designs are great and their facial expressions are well drawn out. Other than that there is nothing really fanciful about the animation here.


Sound: 9/10

Out of the OST, ED 1 & 3 are really good. Kokoro no Kara and Salvage were my favorite songs the moment i heard them. Besides that, the other OPs and EDs were quite decent, and the bgs are simple but fitted the situations when they played. I found the OST to be quite limited though


Character: 10/10

This is the best part about this show! Kokoro Connect has only a few characters, and because of this, the characters are very well developed. It goes from Taichi's sense of justice, Aoki's inferiority, Yui's shyness, Iori's multi-dimensioned personality and Inaba's reservedness. Each of their unique characters initially cause friction against each other, but how they develop and bond together throughout this anime is truly heartwarming. Every experience pulls them together despite their differences. I especially liked the interactions between Inaba and Taichi and their dialogues together


Enjoyment: 9/10

It has a good blend of tension and light-heartedness, which i found to be very enjoyable. 


This is an anime that the drama and slice of life fans shouldn't miss.

Art: The graphics are nothing special or outstanding, you can find this artsytle almost anywhere but it matches the atmosphere of the Anime.
Sound: Great openings and endings, it surprsies me that it had multiple ones since it's pretty short but almostnone of them were memorable so it was a bit disappointing. Same goes to the soundtrack.


Character: Now here comes the strongest point. Seriously, this Anime lives for the characters. Every one of the main characters has it's own personality and no one is alike. None of them feel unnecessary or annoying, their strong hold on each other completes them and they shine with their personalities. No one is abandoned in the dirt, they have equal character development and their own moments. 


Enjoyment: I can't say how entertaining this Anime was for me. The jokes were absolutely spot on, but the characters are what makes this Anime so fun to watch. And the finale made everything even better....


Overall: In my eyes I see Kokoro Connect as the best High School/Slice Of Life Anime that is out there. It's one of my favourites and I would recommend it to everyone out there. These 17 Episodes are absolutely worth it. 


BY THE WAY: Don't forget to watch the OVA of the Anime. It has 4 "special" episodes but they are essential to the story and complete it so don't forget to watch those too!

I have tried watching this anime before a few years back, when I saw it on Crunchyroll, however I did not make it past episode 1. Apparently I was too young then to recognize greatness even when I was looking at it. But I'm so happy I gave it another shot, it has truly been a privilege to watch this show. Very few anime's have a story line that is as great as the one from this anime. It deals with serious problems, but somehow it still managed to make me laugh from time to time. I also think the way that the characters dealwith their problems is very realistic and really pulls you into the show. Kokoro Connect will go down in the books for me as one of the best anime's out there and I highly urge you to check it out.

Kokoro Connect is one of my personal favorite animes of all time. It's a series I watch multiple times a year just because of how much I enjoy it... Now that's not to say this anime doesn't have flaws, every anime has at least a few flaws however it's one of those animes that you love so much that you're able to look past those flaws just because of how much you enjoy it...
Kokoro Connect includes tons of different genres all in one convenient package, from comdey, romance, drama and even a little bit of ecchi. The anime focuses mostly on drama however it's notafraid to add some comedy or ecchi to lighten the scene a little bit. The characters are extremely relatable and not a single person is able to just single handily fix all their problems, they have to help one another through all the problems they will face... Not even the main character Yaegashi Taichi is able to solve his problems on his own, he faces his own issues and is affected by the same things as everyone else. Taichi doesn't just feel like one of those invulnerable main protagonists that face no issues and are able to solve every issue with no problem. Even Taichi will have to rely on his friends every once and a while to remind him that he needs to keep moving forward and that he's not alone.


The plot for Kokoro Connect is amazing, I always love it when animes (espically drama's) deal with heavier topics and issues that LOTS of people deal with on a daily bases. I'm not gonna spoil what happens but if you're going to watch it be prepared for them to be dealing with some controversial subjects. They deal with these topics appropriately and efficently, the way they deal with their issues is very realistic and isn't just some "with the power of friendship we can get through anything and everything with no problem!" crap.


The anime only has 13 episodes and manages to get allot done in such a short amount of time. I'm honestly not a huge fan of the ending but it wasn't necessarily terrible, just ended a little to quickly. This anime may not be for everyone but if you're a fan of drama's like Your Lie in April and Angel Beats I think you'll be able to find some enjoyment in this anime...

I wondered if I should give this show an 8 or a 1.  It wasn't a choice between 7 or 8 or 9, but between 8 and 1.
In categories of plot, dialogue, and characters Kokoro Connect is nothing short of stellar.  For lack of a better expression, I was reminded a lot of Bakemonogatari in terms of both superficial similarities, AND in terms of the subtlety and general quality of the writing.  That is just about the biggest praise I can subjectively crown upon an anime series, and it means that Kokoro Connect is up there with the very best when itcomes to the writing.  That, and the very moment I heard Inaba's voice for the first time, I was like KANBARUUUUUUUU.


Comparisons aside, the general premise of the story is actually somewhat mundane, but that does not work negatively in this case.  The series wastes little time in quickly and efficiently setting up the overall format of the story: a group of 5 high school students being subjected various psychological and social "experiments," during which their secrets, insecurities, and relationships are brutally exposed and tested.  As is frequently stated within the show, it is ultimately an experiment to see how the 5 friends react as a single crucial variable in their lives are tweaked one by one.


Obviously, this kind of plot device lends heavily to character development.  Indeed, the plot itself has no significance other than to drive character development.  In this category, the series also impressed.  The characters, or rather, the way they are written, stand tall among a sea of lesser characters from lesser anime.  To be honest, I have personally outgrown many of the problems and insecurities felt by the very realistic high school student characters, but I could still identify with the characters in a reminiscent manner, if not directly sympathize with them.  I can only guess that the characters hit even closer to home for people in their teens, which I assume would be the target audience.  Just for sake of finding a flaw to talk about, I felt that Aoki was a little lacking.  This fact is actually directly admitted to and discussed within the show, but I still could not help but feel that it was a missed potential.  His character is genuinely likable, especially when he received some long-overdue development, so it was a bit disheartening to see him still relegated as the token comic relief.  Some of his actions and lines are honestly pretty cool, so I wish he could've been written as a slightly more "cool" character, rather than an exclusively comical one.  Later on, during his more serious moments, it felt a bit like Rivalz was trying to act in Suzaku's shoes, to put it into Code Geass terms.  Besides, every other member of the cast is capable of their share of comic relief, so having someone within the MAIN CAST as the exclusive comic relief guy was maybe a bit too much.  But again, that is a minor error that I noticed, and the characters are overall written very, very well.  The more you pay attention to subtle hints, foreshadowing, etc, the more you will catch, adding to your increasing awe of the writing.


HOWEVER, is Kokoro Connect ultimately a top-level, A-class anime?  Frankly not at all.  Note the aspects of the show that I praised: the story, the characters, the writing...  Yes, everything that came from the source material, the light novels, are deserving of the title "masterpiece," but EVERYTHING ELSE is just pathetic, to be quite frank.  I would ruthlessly give the score of 1 or 2 in every technical category, such as quality of animation, sound, etc.  I do concede that many of these problems may stem from budget issues.  I am really willing to give them the benefit of the doubt because the quality is so extraordinarily bad that one assumes there must have been some extenuating circumstance.  The base line of production quality in contemporary works, even the most abysmal ones, is far higher than that exhibited by Kokoro Connect.  Furthermore, the quality skyrockets in the last 4 episodes, which were released some time after the first 13 had aired, no doubt enjoying the financial benefits of the show's success.  This lends further evidence to my "budget issues" theory, but really, the horror of the animation quality in the earlier episodes has to be seen to be believed.


Even after giving the show a benefit of a doubt, there are some unequivocal and undeniable problems.  As always I do not feel good about singling out a creator, a professional in the industry who no doubt knows far more than I do.  However, there is no avoiding the verdict that Kokoro Connect is a very, very, oh so beautifully written, but it is frankly poorly directed.  There is little, if any, variation in camera angle, frame, etc. to aid the dramatic storytelling.  When two characters are talking, it will invariably be a bland two-shot of static frames with only the mouths moving.  When the characters are walking, it will literally be slow-panning profile shot that literally just follows them as they are literally just walking.  You get the point.  Many times, I thought "why even bother to make an anime adaptation?"  It would not have been much different to listen to an audio drama of the original light novel while scrolling through the static images that were already on the LN.  Did they adapt this to a motion picture medium just so we could watch the character's mouths move?  To a certain point, minimalism can be a choice of style, but in case of Kokoro Connect, it doesn't seem to be a conscientious choice, but rather a lack of style and a complete abandoning of the huge potential of visual storytelling inherent in anime as a visual genre.  As I noted above, in terms of writing, Kokoro Connect does many things Bakemonogatari does just as well, but it is absolutely pitiful in comparison to the rich visuals of the latter.  I'm not saying that they should've gone full SHAFT with their trademark splurge visuals, but at least take advantage of the very minimal devices to spice up the stellar story.  Even something as small as 0.5 second of lingering gaze, dramatic camera angle, or a timely zoom-in could add so much punch to the emotional scenes and the surprisingly good humor points.  Instead, the sheer genius of the writing carries this show on its back; it is a lonely, lonely path with zero help from visual storytelling.  That in itself is impressive, I suppose, but also a bit frustrating to watch.  The missed opportunities, the untapped potential.


In the end, I did not have the heart to give this anime adaptation the terrible score it very well deserved.  It is frankly an utter failure as an adaptation.  However, out of respect for the very impressive writing, I decided to take off only 1 point from the absolutely stellar score of 9 and gave it an 8, which, in my standards, is still an A- or a very good B+.

USELESS BONUS CONTENT: Comparison with Bakemonogatari

WARNING. FREE SPOILERS FOR BOTH SERIES. YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED



Many are the reasons I am almost sure that the author had read and was heavily influenced by Bakemonogatari.



-The Male MC is someone who feels compelled to help those around him, even at the cost of great suffering or risk unto himself.


-MC is ultimately monogamous...


-Urban fantasy setting in modern Japan.  High school.


-The supernatural element is deeply psychological and/or existential.


-There is a bizarre and nebulous sense of existential threat looming over every moment of the series.  Highly subjective, admittedly.


-The flashing text panels in KC that just HAVE to be a lame attempt to imitate the iconic device used in Bakemonogatari.


-Extremely tight ensemble cast with few (actually none in BKM) extras.


-Brazenly and gallantly and MONOGAMOUSLY erotic in terms of writing, but not so much visual fanservice. Arguable in BKM, but, say, compared to the standard ecchi anime that would discuss the similar, very explicit  topics ventured in either anime.


-Winning girls possess sharp wit, dark soul, and cold personality.  Their opening up is a central theme.


-Many of the traumatic backstories involve strikingly similar themes, such as being the unknowing perpetrator of blackout violence sprees, rape attempt, bullying, jealousy, etc.  However, one could argue that such themes are ubiquitous in modern anime.


-Sisconic elements.  Though, comparing the sisincest level of KC and BKM would be like comparing your dog to Obama, respectively. 


Only in Bakemonogatari:

-A harem, nay, a demi-harem, thanks to Araragi's unwavering adherence to monogamy


-Sound effects and BGM


-High quality, indeed, legendary visual animation


Only in Kokoro Connect:

-Friendship


-The necessity for an awkward beta-couple arrangement, thanks to Taichi not stepping up to be the Monogamous Harem King that he was born to be.  The Monogamous Harem King is a glorious existence that sits far atop the power ranking pyramid of contemporary anime.

I recommend Kokoro Connect to everyone who loves the slice of life and romance genre
[NO SPOILERS]
Story 10 / 10
Kokoro Connect is one of my personal favorites.
The story itself is absolutely amazing. The writers take something as switching bodies, what has been done over and over by other movies and turn it into something unbelievably good! The way the characters develop throughout the show is outstanding: when you think you know them well enough, another phenomenon occurs which changes your view on them completely. It is because of this great story telling that the overused idea of switching bodies doesn't seem lame but exciting. Although Iwon't spoil anything for you, the other phenomena are even better than the first one, revealing more about the characters, peeling the superficial layer off these kids, showing their true selfs and their desires and dreams.


Because the story is so well written, even though it starts out with, in my opinion, such a boring plot as body switching, it definately desirves a 10 out of 10.



Art 8 / 10


I love the art of Kokoro Connect. Don't get me wrong, it's pretty normal for an anime, but that's why I like it so much. I don't think a different style would suit Kokoro Connect, so to me, they made a good choice just sticking to regular art.



Sound 7 / 10


The OST isn't anything special. The first ending theme of Kokoro Connect however is my favorite ending theme of all time. Look it up, it's called --> Kokoro no kara



Characters 10 / 10


If you would just watch the first couple of episodes of Kokoro Connect, you wouldn't give the characters 10 out of 10. No way you'd give them 10 out of 10. They would be pretty bland: 7 / 10 tops. All characters have their own certain traits. 

Inaba is bossy, cold and strong, Taichi is a goody two-shoes, Nagase is always cheery, Aoki is laid-back and Yui loves karate and cute things.


But through all these phenomena all these things will change. The characters develop so well, that eventually, you WILL bond with them. And at then end of this anime, you will definately give them a 10 out of 10.



Enjoyment 10 / 10


I love this anime. It's truly a masterpiece. Unfortunately I got some interesting anime to watch right now, but the moment I don't, I'm going to rewatch this one. That's how good Kokoro Connect is. None of the episodes are boring or hard to get through. You don't need to sit through the first couple of episodes before you finaly get to the good part. Absolutely not! This anime is fun and interesting from episode 1 to the final episode!


Overall 10 / 10


The writers have taken something as overused as body switching and used it to create a masterpiece. The phenomena create characters that are completely stripped from their superficial layer and show what kind of people they really are.


The art is good though fairly regular and the sound, with a few exceptions (like kokoro no kara) is also nothing special. 


The characters are at first glance normal but reveal themselves to be much more than that.


Overall Kokoro Connect is a masterpiece which I recommend to everyone!

This review contains small spoilers, but not like it will ruin your viewing experience, so I gaurantee you that.

This is one of the most thought-about anime I've seen. The story itself is compleet. It takes a chlichée (Don't you dare to say that swapping bodies isn't clichée.) subject and making it a strong pillar to held on. The story only goes about it, but what they managed to dois fantastic with it. Starting with a not knowing what to do individual teenagers. They decide, because they have to, to group up and make their own club. They become friend, strange things happen, but they make it not like suddenly Taicho evolves into an monster or something. In the later episodes there happens something that is quite unbelievable, but believe me! It makes perfect sense. There is an explenation for it all!

Well I'm getting of tracks. But it has a LOT of good things. But the critic I am, and I know Slice of life isn't all about realism, but purly on showing someones life. But somethings, I've to admit have bother me a little. Character (development)
